My two largest small cap stocks  I own are INSG and AAOI.While they are two completely different companies the reason I own them is basically the same.They both are in a sweet spot for the industry they sell into and will stay there for the next decade.Doesn't mean either will go straight up but it's always easier to make money if you own a company swimming with the current.For INSG it's the FWA market.  It's expected to grow in the 30% annual range for many years.  For AAOI it's the AI data center market which is also expected to grow for at least the next decade.The beauty in both these companies is their runs are still in a very early stage (which ensures they'll be remain very volatile going forward...not for the faint of heart).  But long term, unless something dramatic happens to change market dynamics, the sweet spot they both currently enjoy means the odds will be strongly in their favor of continuing to head north.

Q for DealWithIt and others: I did some digging into the Last 10 K to figure out how much revenue and earnings does the Telematic business contribute to INSG. Here's what I could find:For the last year. Telematics revenue is reported as "Services and Other" for a total revenue of $60M. This includes revenue from their SaaS subscriptions too, unfortunately I couldn't find a breakdown of just Telematics.In the last 10Q their last 6 months revenue called out that "The $4.8 million increase in services and other revenues is primarily due to increased Subscribtion revenues related to the terms of a two-year service contract renewal with a major customer that was effective in April 2024."Meaning the Subscription revenues must be in the range of at least $10 - $20M. That translates to $40M - $50M. of annual revenues by Telematics? If we consider 35% margins on it, since obviously it's a profitable business, or it couldn't be sold for a higher price. Translates to Earnings of $15M. So I think they sold the business at 3 to 4X of their earnings. Sounds like a fair deal! The average seller's discretionary earnings (SDE) multiple for small businesses is between 1.5x and 4.0x.Now coming back to impact on INSG. Clearly the $52M cash coming in will make INSG debt free. That's a clean balance sheet no body thought was possible a year ago. Q3 guidance isn't affected. However in Q4 I feel the quarterly guidance will drop maybe by $7 - $10M as Telematics have exited.Thoughts ??

Bored so decided to make a post about the value of growth and why it's so important in valuing stocks.The analysts have been upgrading their estimates for INSG.  For instance 90 days ago they expected INSG to lose about 8 cents a share in 2025 (not EBITDA but GAAP  numbers). Now they expect INSG to earn .26 cents on 229M in revenue (or about 57M a quarter which is basically flat revenue from what they just posted).If they earn 26 cents that a P/E of 50...which is pretty high.But from a P/S (less than 1) and from a EBTDA number (maybe 4X) it's really cheap.Let's forget those numbers for a moment and just focus on what happens if they post 4 quarters of 65M in 2025.  Very conservative and reasonable to me.That would give them revenue of 260M rather than the 229M current estimate....or another 30M.Only about an 11% growth rate yet how does that translate to earnings?At 40% margins that extra gives them about 12M in additional earnings (remember, at 229M they already have all their bills covered).If there are 14M shares outstanding (let's say the 12.12 warrants are exercised) that's still over 80 cents a share in earnings that go straight to the bottom line.So while revenues only jumped 11% earnings would jump from .26 cents to 1.06.  The P/E would move down from 50 to 11. And that's why when companies that already break evening or better post solid growth numbers their share prices usually skyrocket (and why analysts end up chasing the share price on the way up).
